list.expr: sum(vm_app_version{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(version) unless (sum(vm_app_version{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"} offset $__interval) by(version))
list.name: version change

description: Overview for cluster VictoriaMetrics v1.117.0 or higher

panels.description: How many [data samples](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/keyconcepts/#raw-samples) are in storage
panels.title: Total datapoints

panels.description: Shows the datapoints ingestion rate, including replication factor.
panels.title: Ingestion rate

panels.description: Shows the rate of HTTP read requests.
panels.title: Read requests

panels.description: Total number of available CPUs for all VM components.
panels.title: Available CPU

panels.description: Shows the number of [active time series](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/faq/#what-is-an-active-time-series) with new data points inserted during the last hour. High value may result in ingestion slowdown.
panels.title: Active series

panels.description: Total amount of used disk space
panels.title: Disk space usage

panels.description: Average disk usage per datapoint.
panels.title: Bytes per point

panels.description: Total size of available memory for all VM components.
panels.title: Available memory

panels.description: How many [data samples](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/keyconcepts/#raw-samples) are inserted into cluster per second by protocol before the replication. Check vminsert metrics if there are any issues with ingestion.
panels.title: Datapoints ingestion rate ($instance)

panels.description:
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/write` - insert into VM
* `/metrics` - query VM system metrics
* `/query` - query instant values
* `/query_range` - query over a range of time
* `/series` - match a certain label set
* `/label/{}/values` - query a list of label values (variables mostly)
panels.title: Requests rate ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the number of [active time series](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/faq/#what-is-an-active-time-series) with new data points inserted during the last hour across all storage nodes. High value may result in ingestion slowdown and high memory usage.
panels.title: Active time series ($instance)

panels.description:
The less time it takes is better.
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/write` - insert into VM
* `/metrics` - query VM system metrics
* `/query` - query instant values
* `/query_range` - query over a range of time
* `/series` - match a certain label set
* `/label/{}/values` - query a list of label values (variables mostly)
panels.title: Query duration 0.99 quantile ($instance)

panels.description:
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/write` - insert into VM
* `/metrics` - query VM system metrics
* `/query` - query instant values
* `/query_range` - query over a range of time
* `/series` - match a certain label set
* `/label/{}/values` - query a list of label values (variables mostly)
panels.title: Requests error rate ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the rate of logging the messages by their level. Unexpected spike in rate is a good reason to check logs.
panels.title: Logging rate

panels.description:
Percentage of used RSS memory (resident).
The RSS memory shows the amount of memory recently accessed by the application. It includes anonymous memory and data from recently accessed files (aka page cache).
The application's performance will significantly degrade when memory usage is close to 100%.

Click on the line and choose Drilldown to show memory usage per instance
panels.title: RSS memory % usage ($instance)

panels.description:
Share for memory allocated by the process itself. When memory usage reaches 100% it will be likely OOM-killed.
Safe memory usage % considered to be below 80%

Click on the line and choose Drilldown to show memory usage per instance
panels.title: RSS anonymous memory % usage ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows CPU pressure based on [Pressure Stall Information](https://docs.kernel.org/accounting/psi.html).

The lower the better.
panels.title: CPU pressure

panels.description:
Shows memory pressure based on [Pressure Stall Information](https://docs.kernel.org/accounting/psi.html).

The lower the better.
panels.title: Memory pressure

panels.description: Shows the number of bytes read/write from the storage layer.
panels.title: Disk writes/reads ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the percentage of open file descriptors compared to the limit set in the OS.
Reaching the limit of open files can cause various issues and must be prevented.

See how to change limits here https://medium.com/@muhammadtriwibowo/set-permanently-ulimit-n-open-files-in-ubuntu-4d61064429a
panels.title: Open FDs usage % ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the number of read/write syscalls such as read, pread, write, pwrite.
panels.title: Disk write/read calls ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows IO pressure based on [Pressure Stall Information](https://docs.kernel.org/accounting/psi.html).

The lower the better.
panels.title: IO pressure

panels.description:
Shows the percent of CPU spent on garbage collection.

If % is high, then CPU usage can be decreased by changing GOGC to higher values. Increasing GOGC value will increase memory usage, and decrease CPU usage.

Try searching for keyword `GOGC` at https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/troubleshooting/
panels.title: CPU spent on GC ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the rate of allocations in memory. Sudden increase in allocations would mean increased pressure on Go Garbage Collector and can saturate CPU resources of the application.
panels.title: Memory allocations rate

panels.description:
Shows the time goroutines have spent in runnable state before actually running. The lower is better.

High values or values exceeding the threshold is usually a sign of            insufficient CPU resources or CPU throttling. 

Verify that service has enough CPU resources. Otherwise, the service could work unreliably with delays in processing.
panels.title: Go scheduling latency

panels.description:
Shows the rate and total number of new series created over last 24h.

High [churn rate](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/faq/#what-is-high-churn-rate) tightly connected with database performance and may result in unexpected OOM's or slow queries. It is recommended to always keep an eye on this metric to avoid unexpected [cardinality](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/keyconcepts/#cardinality) "explosions".

The higher churn rate is, the more resources required to handle it. Consider to keep the churn rate as low as possible.

To investigate stats about most expensive series use `api/v1/status/tsdb` handler. More details here https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/cluster-victoriametrics/#url-format

Good references to read:
* https://www.robustperception.io/cardinality-is-key
* https://valyala.medium.com/high-cardinality-tsdb-benchmarks-victoriametrics-vs-timescaledb-vs-influxdb-13e6ee64dd6b
panels.title: Churn rate ($instance)

panels.description:
The percentage of [slow inserts](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/faq/#what-is-a-slow-insert) compared to the total ingestion rate. 

The lower the better. 

In short, slow insert is a cache miss. There are following reasons for slow inserts to go up: 
* Ingestion of completely new, not seen before time series;
* [Re-routing](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/cluster-victoriametrics/#cluster-availability) of series when one or more vmstorage nodes are unavailable;
* Not enough memory to maintain big enough caches for the current workload.

If percentage remains high (>10%) during extended periods of time, then it is likely more RAM is needed for optimal handling of the current number of [active time series](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/faq/#what-is-an-active-time-series). 

See [this issue](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/issues/3976#issuecomment-1476883183) for details.
panels.title: Slow inserts

panels.description: Merge assist happens when vmstorage can't keep up with merging parts. This is usually a sign of overload for vmstorage.
panels.title: Assisted merges ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows % of slow queries according to `search.logSlowQueryDuration` flag, which is `5s` by default.

The less value is better.
panels.title: Slow queries % ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the percentage of used cache size from the allowed size by type. 
Values close to 100% show the maximum potential utilization.
Values close to 0% show that cache is underutilized.
panels.title: Cache usage % by type ($instance)

panels.description: Shows cache miss ratio. Lower is better.

targets.expr:
max(
    rate(vm_cache_misses_total{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}[$__rate_interval])
    /
    rate(vm_cache_requests_total{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}[$__rate_interval])
) by(type)

panels.title: Cache miss ratio ($instance)

panels.description: The value is above 0 when the vmstorage at the given `addr` communicates to the given vminsert node that it cannot accept new data because it is in the read-only mode.
panels.title: Storage in readonly status for vminsert ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows rate of deduplicated samples during [deduplication](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/single-server-victoriametrics/#deduplication) or [downsampling](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/single-server-victoriametrics/#downsampling), according to the configured `-dedup.minScrapeInterval` or `-downsampling.period`.

Should be empty if `-dedup.minScrapeInterval` and `-downsampling.period` isn't set.

Deduplication happens in two places:
* `type="merge"` - during [background merges](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/single-server-victoriametrics/#storage) by vmstorages. Deduplication during merges is permanent.
* `type="select"` - during [read queries](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/keyconcepts/#query-data) by vmselects. Deduplication happens in-flight and has no permanent effect.

The more samples need to be deduplicated, the higher will be resource usage on vmselects or vmstorages.
panels.title: Deduplication rate ($instance)
Samples dropped for last 1h ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the number of partial results served by `vmselects`.

`vmselect` continues serving queries if at least a single vmstorage nodes is available. It marks responses as `partial` for queries served from the remaining healthy vmstorage nodes.

If you prefer consistency over availability then run vmselect nodes with `-search.denyPartialResponse` cmd-line flag. In this case vmselect returns an error if at least a single vmstorage node is unavailable.

See more at [cluster availability](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/cluster-victoriametrics/#cluster-availability).
panels.title: Partial query results ($instance)

targets.expr: sum(flag{is_set="true", job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(job, instance, name, value)

panels.description: Shows the number of restarts per job. The chart can be useful to identify periodic process restarts and correlate them with potential issues or anomalies. Normally, processes shouldn't restart unless restart was inited by user. The reason of restarts should be figured out by checking the logs of each specific service.
panels.title: Restarts ($job)

panels.description:
Shows the amount of data scheduled for [downsampling](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/#downsampling) or [retention filters](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/#retention-filters).

Applying downsampling or retention filters happens in background. `vmstorage` schedules this process periodically when finds data partitions that satisfy configured retention or downsampling rules.

This process could consume additional CPU and Disk IO resources.
panels.title: Partitions scheduled for re-processing

panels.description:
Shows number of pushed and sent rows. 
* `Pushed rows` - rows added to internal inserter buffers before send
* `Sent rows` - successfully transmitted rows to storage nodes

Please note, it could be that `Sent > Pushed` because of the replication factor.
panels.title: Rows ($instance)

panels.description:
Rate of RPC errors by type:
* `Connection` - the number of connection errors to vmstorage node
* `Dial` -  the number of dial errors to vmstorage node.
* `Handshake` - the number of handshake errors to vmstorage node
* `Rerouted` - errors appeared during rerouting of rows from un-healthy storage node to a healthy one.
panels.title: RPC errors ($instance)

panels.description: The number of rows rerouted to the vmstorage node from other nodes when they were unhealthy.
panels.title: Rows ($instance) rerouted to

panels.description: The number of rows rerouted from the vmstorage node to healthy nodes when the given node was unhealthy.
panels.title: Rows ($instance) rerouted from

panels.description: The number of rows or bytes that vminsert internal buffer contains at the moment.
panels.title: Pending

panels.description: Network usage by internal VictoriaMetrics RPC protocol
panels.title: RPC network usage ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the number of datapoints ingested into storage nodes per second. This metric doesn't show all stored datapoints since some of them may be dropped because of wrong timestamps or decode errors.
panels.title: Ingestion rate ($instance)

panels.description:
Share for memory allocated by the process itself. When memory usage reaches 100% it will be likely OOM-killed.
Safe memory usage % considered to be below 80%

Click on the line and choose Drilldown to show memory usage per instance
panels.title: Memory (anon) usage % ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the number of concurrently executed read requests, where:
* `max` - equal to `-search.maxConcurrentRequest` cmd-line flag;
* `current` - current number of concurrent select requests executed by storage.

Each concurrent select request requires RAM, CPU and disk IO resources during processing. Too many concurrent requests could result into OOM exceptions.

When `current` hits `max` constantly, it means storage is overloaded and requires more CPU (see CPU usage) or disks with more IOPS (see disk writes and reads panels in Resource Usage row).

See more at https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/cluster-victoriametrics/#resource-usage-limits
panels.title: Concurrent selects ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows how many ongoing insertions (not API /write calls) on disk are taking place, where:
* `max` - equal to number of CPUs;
* `current` - current number of goroutines busy with inserting rows into underlying storage.

Every successful API /write call results into flush on disk. The `max` is an internal limit and can't be changed. It is always equal to the number of CPUs. 

When `current` hits `max` constantly, it means storage is overloaded and requires more CPU (see CPU usage) or disks with more IOPS (see disk writes and reads panels in Resource Usage row).
panels.title: Concurrent flushes on disk ($instance)

panels.description: The number of rows merged per second by storage nodes. Merge speed depends on available CPU and disk IO bandwidth.
panels.title: Merge speed

panels.description:
The max number of on-going merges across storage nodes.
 The drastic change in number of merges could be a sign of on-going deduplication/downsampling activity.
 It is expected to have high numbers for `storage/small` metric.
panels.title: Active merges ($instance)

panels.description:
The max number of data parts of LSM tree across all storage nodes in the last [partition](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/single-server-victoriametrics/#storage).
Increase in number of parts (the hard limit is 512) is an evidence of slow merge performance - check the resource utilization.
* `indexdb` - inverted index
* `storage/small` - recently added parts of data ingested into storage (hot data)
* `storage/big` -  small parts gradually merged into bigger parts (cold data)
panels.title: LSM parts max by type ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the percentage of used disk space. It is recommended to have at least 20% of free disk space for the best performance.

targets.expr:
max(
    sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(job, instance) /
    (
        sum(vm_free_disk_space_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}-vm_free_disk_space_limit_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(job, instance) +
        sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(job, instance)
    ) 
)

min(
    sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(job, instance) /
    (
        sum(vm_free_disk_space_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}-vm_free_disk_space_limit_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(job, instance) +
        sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(job, instance)
    ) 
)

quantile(0.5,
    sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(job, instance) /
    (
        sum(vm_free_disk_space_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}-vm_free_disk_space_limit_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(job, instance) +
        sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(job, instance)
    ) 
)

panels.title: Disk space usage %  ($instance)

panels.description: How many data points are in RAM queue waiting to be written into storage. The number of pending data points should be in the range from 0 to `5*<ingestion_rate>`, since VictoriaMetrics pushes pending data to persistent storage every 5 seconds. The index datapoints value in general is much lower.
panels.title: Pending datapoints ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the percentage of used disk space by type: datapoints or indexdb. Normally, indexdb takes much less space comparing to datapoints. But with high [churn rate](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/faq/#what-is-high-churn-rate) the size of the indexdb could grow significantly.

The sum of the % can be > 100% since panel shows max % per-job and per-instance. It means different instance can have different ratio between datapoints and indexdb size.

targets.expr:
max(
    sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance", type=~"indexdb.*"}) by(job, instance)
    / 
    sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(job, instance)
)

max(
    sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance", type!~"indexdb.*"}) by(job, instance)
    / 
    sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(job, instance)
)

panels.title: Disk space usage % by type  ($instance)

panels.description: Value > 0 means vmstorage is in readonly mode.
panels.title: Readonly mode

panels.description:
Shows network usage by vmstorage services.
* Writes show traffic sent to clients.
* Reads show traffic received from clients.
panels.title: Network usage ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the max number of existing [snapshots](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/single-server-victoriametrics/#how-to-work-with-snapshots) across vmstorages.

Recently made snapshots do not occupy disk space. But with time, as snapshots become older, they start to occupy more and more disk space.

It is recommended deleting old snapshots when they are no longer needed to free up disk space.
panels.title: Number of snapshots

panels.description: Request rate accepted by vmselect nodes
panels.title: Requests rate ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the max number of concurrent selects across instances.
* `max` limit can be configured via `search.maxConcurrentRequests` flag
* `current` shows the current number of goroutines busy with processing requests

When `current` hits `max` constantly, it means one or more vmselect nodes are overloaded with number of requests. If you observe that CPU for vmselects is saturated, consider adding more vmselect replicas or increase CPU resources. If CPU panel shows a plenty of free resources - try increasing `search.maxConcurrentRequests`.
panels.title: Concurrent selects ($instance)

panels.description:
Share for memory allocated by the process itself. When memory usage reaches 100% it will be likely OOM-killed.
Safe memory usage % considered to be below 80%

Click on the line and choose Drilldown to show memory usage per instance
panels.title: Memory (anon) usage % ($instance)

panels.description: 99th percentile of the number of time series read per query.
panels.title: Series read per query ($instance)

panels.description: 99th percentile of number of [data samples](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/keyconcepts/#raw-samples) read per queried time series.
panels.title: Datapoints read per series ($instance)

panels.description: 99th percentile of number of [data samples](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/keyconcepts/#raw-samples) read per query.
panels.title: Datapoints read per query ($instance)

panels.description:
99th percentile of number of [data samples](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/keyconcepts/#raw-samples) scanner per query.

This number can exceed number of DatapointsReadPerQuery if `step` query arg passed to [/api/v1/query_range](https://prometheus.io/docs/prometheus/latest/querying/api/#range-queries) is smaller than the lookbehind window set in square brackets of [rollup function](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/metricsql/#rollup-functions). For example, if `increase(some_metric[1h])` is executed with the `step=5m`, then the same [data samples](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/keyconcepts/#raw-samples) on a hour time range are scanned `1h/5m=12` times. See [this article](https://valyala.medium.com/how-to-optimize-promql-and-metricsql-queries-85a1b75bf986) for details.
panels.title: Datapoints scanned per query ($instance)

panels.description: Shows network usage between vmselects and clients, such as vmalert, Grafana, vmui, etc.
panels.title: Network usage: clients ($instance)

panels.description: Shows network usage between vmselects and vmstorages.
panels.title: Network usage: vmstorage ($instance)

panels.description:
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/write` - insert into VM
* `/metrics` - query VM system metrics
* `/query` - query instant values
* `/query_range` - query over a range of time
* `/series` - match a certain label set
* `/label/{}/values` - query a list of label values (variables mostly)
panels.title: Requests rate ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the max number of ongoing insertions.
* `max` - equal to number of CPU * 2 by default. May be configured with `maxConcurrentInserts` flag;
* `current` - current number of goroutines busy with processing requests.

`-maxConcurrentInserts` limits the number of insert requests which may be actively processed at any given point in time. All the other insert requests are queued for up to `-insert.maxQueueDuration` in the hope they will get a chance to be processed. This queue is used mostly for absorbing spikes for incoming insert request rate.

When `current` hits `max` constantly, it means vminsert node is overloaded and requires more CPU or higher limits.
panels.title: Concurrent inserts ($instance)

panels.description:
Share for memory allocated by the process itself. When memory usage reaches 100% it will be likely OOM-killed.
Safe memory usage % considered to be below 80%

Click on the line and choose Drilldown to show memory usage per instance
panels.title: Memory (anon) usage % ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the saturation level of connection between vminsert and vmstorage components. 

If the threshold of 0.9sec is reached, then the connection is saturated by more than 90% and vminsert won't be able to keep up. This usually means that either vminsert or vmstorage nodes are struggling with the load. Verify CPU/mem saturation of both components and network saturation between them.
If vminsert resources are saturated - consider adding more resources or scale vminserts horizontally.

If vminsert resources and network are fine, check vmstorage metrics for anomalies.
panels.title: Storage connection saturation ($instance)

panels.description: Shows when vmstorage node is unreachable for vminsert.
panels.title: Storage reachability ($instance)

panels.description: Shows network usage between vminserts and clients, such as vmagent, Prometheus, or any other client pushing metrics to vminsert.
panels.title: Network usage: clients ($instance)

panels.description: Shows network usage between vminserts and vmstorages.
panels.title: Network usage: vmstorage ($instance)

options.content: Drilldown row is used by other panels on the dashboard to show more detailed metrics per-instance.

panels.description:
Shows the used memory (resident).
The application's performance will significantly degrade when memory usage is close to 100%.
panels.title: RSS memory usage ($instance)

panels.description: RSS share for memory allocated by the process itself. This share cannot be freed by the OS, so it must be taken into account by OOM killer.
panels.title: RSS anonymous memory usage ($instance)

targets.expr:
(vm_free_disk_space_bytes{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance"}-vm_free_disk_space_limit_bytes{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance"}) 
/ 
ignoring(path) (
    (rate(vm_rows_added_to_storage_total{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance"}[1d]) - 
        sum(rate(vm_deduplicated_samples_total{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance"}[1d])) without (type)) * 
    (
        sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance", type!~"indexdb.*"}) without(type) /
        sum(vm_rows{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance", type!~"indexdb.*"}) without(type)
    )
    +
    rate(vm_new_timeseries_created_total{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance"}[1d]) * 
    (
        sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance", type="indexdb/file"}) /
        sum(vm_rows{job=~"$job_storage", instance=~"$instance", type="indexdb/file"})
    )
) > 0

panels.title: Storage full ETA ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the percentage of used disk space. It is recommended to have at least 20% of free disk space for the best performance.
panels.title: Disk space usage ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the rate of logging the messages by their level. Unexpected spike in rate is a good reason to check logs.
panels.title: Logging rate

title: VictoriaMetrics - cluster
